name: Sal's Fractured Salad Bar Online Trivia | Fractured Words | 10 Questions

questions.text:
Sal went to the head of the salad bar, grabbed a chilled plate, and began his salad creation by putting this on his plate. Can you decipher the fracture word? 

FRACTURED WORD: Eyes Bur Gladys
questions.explanation:
Iceberg Lettuce.

	Iceberg lettuce, also known as crisphead lettuce, has a crunchy texture and mild flavor that makes it a popular base for many salads.

questions.text:
Sal wanted some protein added to his meal so he was happy to see the next item on the salad bar. What did he scoop upon his plate? 

FRACTURED WORD: Caught Itch Ease
questions.explanation:
Cottage Cheese.

	Cottage cheese was promoted during WWI as a meat substitute in order to save meat for the troops. After the war, it grew in popularity and became a staple in most homes.

questions.text:
Sal's eyes popped wide when he saw his favorite green vegetable on the salad bar. What did he add to his salad? 

FRACTURED WORD: Spend itch
questions.explanation:
Spinach.

	Spinach originated in Persia and was made popular in the 20th century by the animated Popeye the Sailorman. It is a great source for vitamin K.

questions.text:
Sal wanted to add some fruit to his salad. What did he put on his plate? 

FRACTURED WORD: Cheery Toe Mate Tows
questions.explanation:
Cherry Tomatoes.

	Cherry tomatoes are smaller than most tomatoes. They can range in size from the tip of an adult's thumb to about the size of a golf ball.

questions.text:
Sal was looking for something sweet to put on his salad plate. He saw a crock blanketed in ice with a sign that read delicious and good for you. It looked appealing so he spooned some on his plate. what did Sal add? 

FRACTURED WORD: A Pull Saws
questions.explanation:
Applesauce.

	Applesauce has been around since Medieval times. In some countries it is served as a dessert while other countries use it as a side for meat dishes. It is high in vitamin C, fiber and pectin.

questions.text:
Sal looked in the next bowl on the salad bar and thought the contents looked cool, so he took some. What did Sal add to his salad? 

FRACTURED WORD: Queue Comb Oars
questions.explanation:
Cucumbers.

	Cucumbers have been cultivated into several groups. Three of the most popular are: Slicing cucumbers which are made to eat fresh, gherkins which are used for pickling and burpless which are known for their sweet taste.

questions.text:
Sal's thought it was "the pits" that he could not have dessert, so he decided to make his salad bigger by adding on some more items. What did Sal add to his salad? 

FRACTURED WORD:  All Leaves
questions.explanation:
Olives.

	Green olives are olives that are picked while unripe. Black olives are fully matured ripe olives. Both colors are popular items on a salad bar.

questions.text:
Sal wanted a little crunch in his salad so he added this item. With what did Sal top off his salad? 

FRACTURED WORD: Crew Towns
questions.explanation:
Croutons.

	A crouton is a piece of re-baked bread that has been seasoned and formed into cubes. The name comes from the French word meaning "crust".

questions.text:
Sal felt like a hog, because his plate was piled high with food. But he needed a little meat on his plate. What did Sal sprinkle on his salad? 

FRACTURED WORD: Bake Own Pea Seas
questions.explanation:
Bacon Pieces.

	The popularity of bacon exploded in the 1990s, especially in North America. It is not used only as a breakfast meat but it is now dipped in chocolate and used as a dessert, it is infused in whiskey and added to everything from jam to catsup. The mania surrounding bacon has been linked to an increased interest in high protein diets.

questions.text:
Sal's salad looked delicious. The final touch would make his masterpiece complete. What did he pour on his salad?

FRACTURED WORD: Eat Tail Leaned Racing
questions.explanation:
Italian Dressing.

	Ironically Italian dressing was created in the USA. It is thought that Florence Hanna, the daughter of Italian immigrants, made the first batch of what became known as Italian dressing.
